root: ^Strong! I can now do the monkey bars, all the way to the end! I'm so proud; I want to show %FirstName:NPC:1%... But %FirstName:NPC:1% can't do them, he gets puffed and has to drop down at the end.
^Should I show him what I can do or not?
^Yes, do the monkey bars. He's my friend, he'll be happy for me!

res1: ^I don't know whether he was jealous or just annoyed with himself, but %FirstName:NPC:1% got moody. He didn't congratulate me or anything. We kind of fell out.

^I suppose you shouldn't show off what you can do, or you should just be more careful about it. I could do the monkey bars, but %FirstName:NPC:1% couldn't, and didn't appreciate me showing him how it was done.
res2: ^%FirstName:NPC:1% was so chuffed when I offered to help him with the monkey bars, and all he needed was a little lift. I got a chance to demonstrate too, and he high fived me!
^I helped %FirstName:NPC:1% with his monkey bar skills. I love hanging with my mates!
res3: ^%FirstName:NPC:1% and I had a funny game of doctors and nurses, and left the park tired and still friends. I wished I could've shown him the monkey bars, but I guess I saved his feelings.
^Is it always good to be modest? Sometimes I think it's important to show people what you can do! I guess I spared %FirstName:NPC:1%'s feelings, but so what if I can do the monkey bars and he can't!
global decl: ^Should I show him what I can do or not?
